member.name: T:Sims.Far.Far
member.summary: The FAR format (.far files) are used to bundle (archive) multiple files together. All numeric values in the header and manifest are stored in little-endian order(least significant byte first).

member.name: P:Sims.Far.Far.Signature
member.summary: The signature is an eight-byte string, consisting literally of "FAR!byAZ" (without the quotes).

member.name: P:Sims.Far.Far.Version
member.summary: The version is always one.

member.name: P:Sims.Far.Far.ManifestOffset
member.summary: The manifest offset is the byte offset from the beginning of the file to the manifest. The contents of the archived files are simply concatenated together without any other structure or padding.Caveat: all of the files observed have been a multiple of four in length, so it's possible that the files may be padded to a two-byte or four-byte boundary and the case has simply never been encountered.

member.name: P:Sims.Far.Far.Manifest
member.summary: The manifest contains a count of the number of archived files, followed by an entry for each file. In all of the examples examined the order of the entries matches the order of the archived files, but whether this is a firm requirement or not is unknown.

member.name: M:Sims.Far.Far.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: The Far constructor.
member.param: The path to the far file.

member.name: M:Sims.Far.Far.GetBytes(System.String)
member.summary: Return a byte array for a file name in the far. The file name must be exact.
member.param: The name of the file in the far.
member.returns: A byte array of the content in the far.

member.name: M:Sims.Far.Far.TryGetBytes(System.String,System.Byte[]@)
member.summary: Try to return a byte array for a file name in the fire. The file name must be exact.
member.param: The name of the file in the far
A byte array to receive the bytes
member.returns: Whether or not the file was found in the .far

member.name: M:Sims.Far.Far.GetBytes(Sims.Far.ManifestEntry)
member.summary: Return a byte array for the given Manifest entry.
member.returns: A byte array of the content in the far.

member.name: M:Sims.Far.Far.Extract(Sims.Far.ManifestEntry,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Extract a file by its manifest entry from the far.
member.param: The directory to extract the files to. Otherwise it will extract them at the current directory.

Whether or not to create the directories from a filename. If a filename was Community\Bus_loadscreen_800x600.bmp, Community\ would or wouldn't be created depending on this parameter. true = create it, false = strip it.

member.name: M:Sims.Far.Far.Extract(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Extract a file(s) by its file name in the far. If the the Manifest entry file name contains a directory, you must include that exactly.
member.param: The filename of the Manifest entry.
The directory to extract the files to. Otherwise it will extract them at the current directory.

Whether or not to create the directories from a filename. If a filename was Community\Bus_loadscreen_800x600.bmp, Community\ would or wouldn't be created depending on this parameter. true = create it, false = strip it.

member.name: T:Sims.Far.Manifest
member.summary: The manifest contains a count of the number of archived files, followed by an entry for each file. In all of the examples examined the order of the entries matches the order of the archived files, but whether this is a firm requirement or not is unknown.

member.name: P:Sims.Far.Manifest.NumberOfFiles
member.summary: The number of files in the far file.

member.name: P:Sims.Far.Manifest.ManifestEntries
member.summary: A list of Manifest Entries in the far file.

member.name: T:Sims.Far.ManifestEntry
member.summary: A manifest entry containing the first file length, second file length, file offset, file name length, and file name.

member.name: P:Sims.Far.ManifestEntry.FileLength1
member.summary: The file length is stored twice. Perhaps this is because some variant of FAR files supports compressed data and the fields would hold the compressed and uncompressed sizes, but this is pure speculation. The safest thing to do is to leave the fields identical.

member.name: P:Sims.Far.ManifestEntry.FileLength2
member.summary: The file length is stored twice. Perhaps this is because some variant of FAR files supports compressed data and the fields would hold the compressed and uncompressed sizes, but this is pure speculation. The safest thing to do is to leave the fields identical.

member.name: P:Sims.Far.ManifestEntry.FileOffset
member.summary: The file offset is the byte offset from the beginning of the FAR file to the archived file.

member.name: P:Sims.Far.ManifestEntry.FilenameLength
member.summary: The filename length is the number of bytes in the filename. Filenames are stored without a terminating null. For example, the filename "foo" would have a filename length of three and the entry would be nineteen bytes long in total.

member.name: P:Sims.Far.ManifestEntry.Filename
member.summary: The name of the file. This can include directories.

member.name: P:Sims.Far.IFar.Manifest
member.summary: The manifest contains a count of the number of archived files, followed by an entry for each file. In all of the examples examined the order of the entries matches the order of the archived files, but whether this is a firm requirement or not is unknown.

member.name: P:Sims.Far.IFar.ManifestOffset
member.summary: The manifest offset is the byte offset from the beginning of the file to the manifest. The contents of the archived files are simply concatenated together without any other structure or padding.Caveat: all of the files observed have been a multiple of four in length, so it's possible that the files may be padded to a two-byte or four-byte boundary and the case has simply never been encountered.

member.summary: The signature is an eight-byte string, consisting literally of "FAR!byAZ" (without the quotes).

The contents of the archived files are simply concatenated together without any other structure or padding.Caveat: all of the files observed have been a multiple of four in length, so it's possible that the files may be padded to a two-byte or four-byte boundary and the case has simply never been encountered.

Whether or not to create the directories from a filename. If a filename was Community\Bus_loadscreen_800x600.bmp, Community\ would or wouldn't be created depending on this parameter. true = create it, false = strip it.
